Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Vicarious Liability: The Underlying Roles of Blame and Collective Responsibility

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vicarious liability claims against employers for damages or injuries caused by their employees are among the most common civil claims in the United States. In a vicarious liability case, no fault is required; even a perfectly careful, non-negligent employer can be held liable for an employee?s careless actions. Legal and business commentators in the U.S., U.K., and Australia have criticized this form of liability as not only unfair to employers, but also inconsistently applied by courts.

This research will examine victim likeability, outcome severity, and group entitativity (i.e., the degree to which group members are interdependent and close) as possible psychological explanations for inconsistent court decisions in vicarious liability cases in the business context. Previous studies have shown that a perpetrator is blamed more, and is thereby assigned greater legal liability, for harming a likable compared to an unlikeable victim. Similarly, when a person's action results in a severe outcome, they are blamed more than if the same action results in a less severe outcome. Furthermore, blame is often "transferred" from an individual to his or her social group when entitativity is high. The current research aims to expand the focus from individuals and social groups to include business situations. The researchers will analyze a randomly selected sample of previously rendered state court decisions to determine whether the psychological factors might have influenced the decisions; run a series of studies to create a philosophically sound measure of blame; and run an experiment in which participants make blame and vicarious liability judgments after watching a video depiction of a trial in which the psychological factors are manipulated.

This doctoral research project expands our understanding of blame and its transference beyond individuals (e.g., criminal defendants) and social groups (e.g., families) to include businesses, thereby potentially informing and guiding future vicarious liability litigation. The project involves graduate and undergraduate students, many of whom are from underrepresented groups, in research. Results from the studies will be disseminated to both the legal and psychological communities and may inform and guide future vicarious liability litigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. legal system generally imposes liability only upon individuals who directly engage in prohibited behaviors or negligently cause harmful outcomes. However, because these individuals often do not have much money or hard to locate, it is impractical for plaintiffs to pursue them for compensation. To address this, vicarious liability allows liability to be imposed upon an entity or organization for the actions of another. For example, in an employment setting, vicarious liability allows liability to be imposed on an employer for the actions of an employee and does not involve a determination of fault on the part of the employer. Thus, if a plaintiff attempts to hold an employer vicariously liable for the damages its negligent employee caused, a jury’s only task is to determine whether the negligent action was within the scope of employment.

Previous research suggests that people are influenced by a host of extralegal psychological factors when imposing legal responsibility or liability upon defendants, and people’s notions of blameworthiness appear to be crucial in this determination (Alicke, 2000).  The research demonstrates that people assign blame through a dual process in which they spontaneously respond positively or negatively to features of an event (e.g., person’s likeability) (Bradfield & Aquino, 1999), and then use a controlled process to interpret the features in a manner consistent with the spontaneous response (Alicke, 2000). For example, positive features such as attractiveness of an actor may reduce blame while negative features such as outcome severity or the type of weapon used may increase blame (Bradfield & Aquino, 1999). Furthermore, blame may also be transferred from an individual to a group to which that individual belongs –called collective responsibility (Lickel, Schmader, & Hamilton, 2003).   Entitativity seems to be the primary factor that influences this blame transference and involves the degree to which members of a group are interdependent on each other (Lickel, Schmader, & Hamilton, 2003).

The current research aimed to expand understanding of blame and legal responsibility by examining whether and how blame is transferred from employee to employer, as well as the relation between such transferred blame and the imposition of vicarious liability on the employer. Specifically, we examined the influence of victim likeability, outcome severity, and entitativity on blame and vicarious liability. In doing so, we created a blame scale that focuses on the affective, behavioral, and cognitive components of blame.  We also expanded an area of research that had been primarily limited to social relationships into business relationships.

The study randomly assigned participants (456 community members recruited from Amazon’s M-Turk) to one of sixteen experimental conditions created by manipulating victim likeability (high or low), outcome severity (high or low), entitativity (high or low), and weapon type (gun or bottle) in a  video depicting an abridged civil trial. Each video was approximately 25 minutes long and based on a combination of two real employment cases. The data generally supported that both victim likeability and outcome severity increased blame assigned to the employee. Although blame assigned to the employee did not generally predict blame assigned to the employer, the affective component of blame increased the likelihood of vicarious liability judgment, while the cognitive component decreased the likelihood. It appears that blame—specifically, emotional blame-- is either transferred to the employer directly or through a mechanism that was not examined. Such a finding contributes to the broader dialogue about whether court decisions are consistent with the general public’s notions of blame and responsibility.
